articles.headline: Saudi Prince ‘Complicit’ in Khashoggi’s Murder, Senators Say After C.I.A. Briefing
articles.snippet: “There is not a smoking gun, there’s a smoking saw,” Senator Lindsey Graham said after hearing from the C.I.A. director, Gina Haspel.
articles.abstract: “There is not a smoking gun, there’s a smoking saw,” Senator Lindsey Graham said after hearing from the C.I.A. director, Gina Haspel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senior senators said on Tuesday that a classified briefing by the C.I.A. director had only solidified their belief that Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, ordered the killing of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Steve Bannon and a Fugitive Billionaire Target a Common Enemy: China
articles.snippet: “We both naturally despise the Chinese Communist Party,” the fugitive, Guo Wengui said, explaining his partnership with the former Trump strategist Stephen K. Bannon.
articles.abstract: “We both naturally despise the Chinese Communist Party,” the fugitive, Guo Wengui said, explaining his partnership with the former Trump strategist Stephen K. Bannon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just months after being pushed out of the White House, Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former chief strategist, met with a fugitive Chinese billionaire at a suite in the luxurious Hays-Adams Hotel in Washington.

articles.headline: Trump Warns China That He’s ‘Tariff Man,’ Spooking Stock Investors
articles.snippet: Stocks, which rallied Monday on the potential for a truce in the United States-China trade war, began a downward spiral on Tuesday as confusion set in about whether an agreement had truly been reached.
articles.abstract: Stocks, which rallied Monday on the potential for a truce in the United States-China trade war, began a downward spiral on Tuesday as confusion set in about whether an agreement had truly been reached.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trade war is back on — at least as far as investors are concerned.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: House Republican Campaign Committee Says It Was Hacked This Year
articles.snippet: The National Republican Congressional Committee said it had reported the breach to the F.B.I. but acknowledged that it had otherwise kept the hack secret for months.
articles.abstract: The National Republican Congressional Committee said it had reported the breach to the F.B.I. but acknowledged that it had otherwise kept the hack secret for months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The campaign committee for House Republicans discovered in April that the email accounts of several of its senior officials had been hacked by what analysts later concluded was a “foreign entity,” people who have been briefed on the case said on Tuesday, highlighting the continued vulnerability of the United States to interference in its elections.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Digital Divide Is Wider Than We Think, Study Says
articles.snippet: New research from Microsoft says that far fewer people have broadband internet access than government statistics have shown.
articles.abstract: New research from Microsoft says that far fewer people have broadband internet access than government statistics have shown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ferry County in northeastern Washington spans more than 2,200 square miles of mostly forestland, rivers and lakes. And according to the Federal Communications Commission, everyone in the sprawling county has access to broadband internet.

articles.headline: Les Moonves Obstructed Investigation Into Misconduct Claims, Report Says
articles.snippet: Leslie Moonves, the former CBS chief, destroyed evidence and misled investigators looking into his alleged misconduct, according to a draft of a report prepared for the company’s board.
articles.abstract: Leslie Moonves, the former CBS chief, destroyed evidence and misled investigators looking into his alleged misconduct, according to a draft of a report prepared for the company’s board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing multiple sexual misconduct allegations and fearing his career as an entertainment titan was over, Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of CBS, destroyed evidence and misled investigators in an attempt to preserve his reputation and save a lucrative severance deal, according to a draft of a report prepared for the company’s board.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Edmund Lee

articles.headline: ‘Disaster for CBS Shareholders’: Damning Report on Moonves Reveals Total Failure at Top
articles.snippet: Senior executives and board members at CBS knew about allegations of sexual misconduct by Leslie Moonves, the chief executive. No one acted to stop him.
articles.abstract: Senior executives and board members at CBS knew about allegations of sexual misconduct by Leslie Moonves, the chief executive. No one acted to stop him.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a draft report prepared by CBS’s outside lawyers now makes clear, many of the company’s employees, including high-ranking executives and even members of its board, were aware of the former chief executive Leslie Moonves’s alleged sexual misconduct and subsequent efforts to conceal it.

articles.headline: Michael Flynn Was a Key Cooperator and Should Serve Little Prison Time, Mueller Says
articles.snippet: Mr. Flynn has pleaded guilty to lying to investigators about conversations he had with the Russian ambassador to the United States during the presidential transition.
articles.abstract: Mr. Flynn has pleaded guilty to lying to investigators about conversations he had with the Russian ambassador to the United States during the presidential transition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, helped substantially with the special counsel’s investigation and should receive little to no prison time for lying to federal investigators, prosecutors said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Wisconsin Republicans Defiantly Move to Limit the Power of Incoming Democrats
articles.snippet: Robin Vos, the speaker of the Assembly, was the first official to publicly suggest that Republicans consider reining in the powers of the state’s newly elected Democrats.
articles.abstract: Robin Vos, the speaker of the Assembly, was the first official to publicly suggest that Republicans consider reining in the powers of the state’s newly elected Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — When Wisconsin Republicans pushed through a sweeping set of bills Wednesday to limit the power of the state’s newly elected Democrats, it was another hardball maneuver by a man who has played a key role in driving the state sharply to the right.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Facebook Used People’s Data to Favor Certain Partners and Punish Rivals, Documents Show
articles.snippet: A trove of internal Facebook documents was released by a British parliamentary committee as part of an investigation into misinformation and user data.
articles.abstract: A trove of internal Facebook documents was released by a British parliamentary committee as part of an investigation into misinformation and user data.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook used the mountains of data it collected on users to favor certain partners and punish rivals, giving companies such as Airbnb and Netflix special access to its platform while cutting off others that it perceived as threats.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Mike Isaac
